light source.source: A 300 W Xe arc lamp (Aulight CEL-HXF300, Beijing) equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter was served as the light source.
light source.context: The chemical reagents were purchased from accredited suppliers.They included Dicyandiamide (C 2 H 4 N 4 , 99) and Indium(III) chloride tetrahydrate (InCl 3 A4H 2 O, 99.9) from Aladdin, Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, 97) from Shanghai HUSHI, and Sodium hydroxide (NaCl, 99.8) and L-Cysteine (C 3 H 7 NO 2 S, 99) from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.All chemical reagents were used directly without further purification.The water used in all experiments was purified through a Millipore system. Precisely, 1.0 g dicyandiamide with 30.0 g NaCl were mixed by ball-milling at 300 r/ min for 2 h, and 1 mL NaOH solution (20 g/L) was dropped into the above powder.Then it was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 60 C for 16 h.The mixture was placed in a temperature-programmed tubular furnace for calcining 4 h at 550 C, with the constant heating rate (2.0 CAmin A1 ) under N 2 atmosphere.Finally, the obtained product was washed with a large amount of deionized water for six times to remove superficial NaCl, and then it was collected by vacuum drying.(marked as NDCN) Precisely, InCl 3 A4H 2 O (1 mmol) with 20 mL deionized water and L-Cysteine (3 mmol) with 40 mL deionized water were stirred together for 30 min.Then 1 M NaOH solution was used to adjust the pH of the mixed solution until the pH value changed to 8. The resultant solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated in an oven at 180 C for 10 h.After the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by suction filtration, washed with deionized water for several times, and then dried at 60 C for 12 h.The obtained product is amorphous In 2 S 3 . The b-In 2 S 3 /NDCN samples were synthesized by the evaporation and re-sintering method.As shown in scheme 1, a certain amount of flaky NDCN and the appropriate prepared amorphous In 2 S 3 were added to 60 mL ethanol, and then the mixture was treated by ultrasonic and stirring for three cycles.Subsequently, the mixture suspension was stirred at 80 C until the ethanol volatilized completely.Finally, the dried mixture powder was placed in a temperature-programmed tubular furnace for calcining 10 min at 330 C, with the constant heating rate (5.0 CAmin A1 ) under N 2 atmosphere.The obtained samples with different content of In 2 S 3 were named as 10 b-In 2 S 3 /NDCN, 20 b-In 2 S 3 /NDCN, 30 b-In 2 S 3 /NDCN.Moreover, the pure b-In 2 S 3 was prepared without NDCN, remarked as b-In 2 S 3 . Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were carried out on Bruker D2 PHASER.Field emission scanning electron microscopy (JSM-IT500HR) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (JEOLJEM 2100) with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) were employed to estimate the composition and morphologies of synthesized materials.The Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to observe the fine structure of the samples.Brunner Emmet Teller (BET) measurements were performed on Micro ASAP 2460 with nitrogen adsorption at 77 K, and the Pretreatment degassing temperature was 150 C.Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was recorded on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer.The UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were conducted on a Shimadzu UV-2600 UV-vis spectrophotometer with a wavelength range of 220-800 nm.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out with a Thermo-VG Scientific Escalab 250 spectrometer to approximate the assessment of sample element ratio.CO 2 temperatureprogrammed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) measurement with 0.1 g catalyst was performed on micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The photo-electrochemical measurements of required samples were carried out on a CHI 760D electrochemical workstation (Shanghai Chenhua, China).A standard three-electrode pool includes a working electrode, a Pt wire as counter electrode, and a standard Ag/AgCl in saturated KCl as the reference electrode.0.5 M Na 2 SO 4 solution was used as the electrolyte.The working electrode was prepared as follows: 5 mg of the catalyst was added into the mixture of 30 lL Nafion solution and 1 mL of ethyl alcohol for 2 h under ultrasonically scattering.Then, the slurry was dropped onto a 1 cm A 1 cm FTO glass electrode with the help of scotch tape at a rate of 50 Aml for six times.Finally, the obtained film was dried in a vacuum at 80 C for 12 h.The Mott-Schottky (MS) were recorded at a frequency of 1000 Hz under dark conditions.The light on-off cycle per 20 s was employed in photocurrent (IT-Curve) under light irradiation (420 nm), and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) were tested under an AC perturbation signal of 10 mV. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 activity test was carried out at the gas-solid phase system.The photocatalyst (5 mg) and 1 mL deionized water (1 mL) were evenly mixed and dripped on the frosted glass.Deionized water (20 mL) was added to a glass reactor (80 mL incapacity) to provide adequate water vapor, and the frosted glass in the reactor was about 7 cm away from the light source.Then, the high-purity CO 2 (99.99) was vacuumed for three times alternately to displace the residual air in the system.Finally, the reactor was filled with CO 2 at a pressure of 80 Kpa, and the circulating water temperature was set at 25 C.A 300 W Xe arc lamp (Aulight CEL-HXF300, Beijing) equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter was served as the light source.The gas-phase products were detected and quantified by gas chromatography (Techcomp GC 7900) with both TCD and FID detectors at 2 h intervals. The apparent quantum yield (AQY) of gas phase products (CO and CH 4 ) was calculated by the following formula: 20,21.For pure NDCN, the typical characteristic peaks at 13.1and 27.4b elonged to (1 0 0) and (0 0 2) crystal planes, respectively, representing the in-plane repeated structural units and the interlayer structural stacking reflection of the conjugated aromatic system 24,25 Then the microstructures topography of as-synthesized samples were observed through SEM, TEM, HRTEM and EDS, further confirming the combination of b-In 2 S 3 /NDCN composites.As shown in Fig. 2a, the pure NDCN exhibited irregular and unsmooth lamellar structure with some pores of uneven size.Due to this ultrathin structure, electrons could be quickly transferred to the surface to promote the reaction and a large number of scattered flakes, to a certain extent, provided more exposed active sites 26.From Fig. 2c, the pure b-In 2 S 3 sample presented an obvious surface fold ball-flower structure and the diameters of these balls were mostly concentrated in 2 lm.Such a kind of grooved surface rather than a solid ball structure could contribute to enhancing light absorption utilization 27.After introducing b-In 2 S 3 into NDCN, the morphology of two materials was nearly unchanged and dispersed b-In 2 S 3 ball-flower anchor on the surface of NDCN (Fig. 2e), forming a heterojunction structure.In the HRTEM image (Fig. 3e), it can be seen that the high crystallinity b-In 2 S 3 presented obvious lattice fringes with the width of 0.31 nm and 0.60 nm corresponding to the b-In 2 S 3 (3 1 1) and (1 1 1) crystal plane 22.Whereas no obvious lattice fringes of NDCN were observed due to its low crystallinity.Moreover, the elements C, N, Na, In and S were all detected in 20 b-In 2 S 3 / NDCN from the mapping, revealing that the intimate attachment of b-In 2 S 3 on the NDCN.The above results indicate that the successful construction of heterojunction, and is crucial for effective electrons transfer.
